div.h1: x86 Privilege Rings: Ring 0 to Ring 3 Full Picture

p.strong: Hardware-enforced privilege hierarchy CPL bits in CS register [1:0]

g.text: Ring 1 and Ring 2 Unused in Modern OS Design
QEMU TCG: Guest Ring 0 in Host Ring 3

ul.li: HLT halt CPU until next interrupt
LGDT / LIDT load GDT / IDT register
MOV CRn read/write CR0 CR2 CR3 CR4
IN / OUT I/O port access (any port)
Device drivers: VGA serial PIT PS/2

div.p: IN AL,DX and OUT DX,AL at ring 0: always legal

ul.li: Ring 1: OS services and device drivers
Hierarchical: ring N can access rings above N
Never adopted by Unix, Windows NT, or Linux
Portability: ARM MIPS RISC-V have no intermediate rings
Unix philosophy: kernel/user binary split is sufficient
Complexity: DPL=1/2 GDT entries and call gates needed
Modern replacement: VMX root mode below ring 0
Today: ring 1/2 GDT entries absent from Linux GDT
Windows NT designed for portability: skipped rings 1/2

p.strong: VMX Root Mode Ring minus 1 (Intel VT-x)

div.p: Hypervisors VMware KVM Hyper-V run BELOW ring 0. Guest OS ring 0 runs in VMX non-root mode. Privileged instructions trigger VM exits to hypervisor. QEMU/KVM: guest CR3 writes go through EPT. EPT: guest-physical to host-physical addr in HW.

ul.li: MOV CR0 / MOV CR3 / MOV CR4 GPF
IN / OUT if IOPL less than CPL=3 GPF

div.p: CPU checks CPL vs DPL on every privileged instruction

ul.li: All arithmetic logic and branch instructions
Memory read/write within mapped permitted pages
INT n if IDT gate DPL >= CPL (else GPF)
INT 0x80 syscall gate (IDT DPL=3 trap gate)
Application code: C Rust Python interpreter etc.
QEMU TCG: guest ring-0 code runs in HOST ring-3
Privileged instruction causes SIGSEGV caught by QEMU
QEMU emulates the effect and resumes guest at next instr

p.strong: Memory Isolation via Page Table U/S Bit (PTE bit 2)

ul.li: U/S = 0 (Supervisor): ring 0 only; ring 3 access causes PF

div.p: Page fault error code bit 2 = 1 means user-mode violation. CR2 holds faulting virtual address.
SMEP (CR4 bit 20): ring-3 cannot EXECUTE U/S=0 pages. Blocks ret2usr: attacker jumps kernel EIP to user shellcode.
SMAP (CR4 bit 21): ring-0 cannot READ U/S=1 pages without STAC. Blocks kernel accidentally dereferencing user pointers.
KPTI: user page directory has NO kernel mappings. Double CR3 swap per syscall Meltdown mitigation.
Bits 15-3 = Index into GDT (0 = null descriptor) Bit 2 = TI: 0=GDT 1=LDT Bits 1-0 = RPL: Requested Privilege Level (0-3)

Kernel CS = 0x08 = index 1 TI=0 RPL=0 CPL becomes 0 Kernel DS = 0x10 = index 2 TI=0 RPL=0 User CS = 0x1B = index 3 TI=0 RPL=3 CPL becomes 3 User DS = 0x23 = index 4 TI=0 RPL=3 TSS sel = 0x28 = index 5 TI=0 RPL=0

p.strong: DPL Field in GDT Descriptor (Access Byte bits 6:5)

div.p: Access byte: P | DPL[1:0] | S | Type[3:0]
DPL = 0: only ring 0 can load this selector. DPL = 3: any ring can load this selector. GDT enforcement: if CPL > DPL of descriptor GPF.
IDT gate DPL enforcement (for INT n): If CPL > IDT gate DPL GPF. INT 0x80 gate DPL=3: user mode can invoke it. IRQ handler gates DPL=0: only hardware/ring-0 can invoke.

p.strong: CPL = Current Privilege Level = CS bits 1:0

div.p: CPU tracks CPL continuously during execution. CPL changes only on: iret far-jump SYSCALL SYSENTER.
Ring 3 to Ring 0 path: INT/exception fires CPU reads TSS.ESP0. Loads kernel SS:ESP from TSS. Pushes old SS ESP EFLAGS CS EIP onto kernel stack. Loads CS from IDT gate CPL becomes 0.

Ring 0 to Ring 3 path: IRET pops EIP CS EFLAGS. Detects CS.RPL=3 > current CPL=0 privilege transition. Pops user ESP SS switches back to user stack. CPL becomes 3 atomically with EFLAGS restore (IF bit).

g.text: Ring 3 to Ring 0: Interrupt / Exception / Syscall

p.strong: QEMU Tiny Code Generator software emulation mode

div.p: Host OS: Linux ring 3 (QEMU is a normal user process). Guest: your x86 kernel including ring 0 code.
Translation flow for privileged guest instruction:

ol.li: Guest ring-0 instruction fetched e.g. MOV CR3,EAX
TCG detects privileged opcode during translation
Generates host code calling QEMU helper function
Helper emulates the effect (updates virtual CR3)
Guest execution continues at next guest instruction

div.p: Guest HLT: QEMU pauses vCPU thread until virtual IRQ. Guest LGDT: QEMU updates internal GDT base/limit vars. Guest INT 0x80: QEMU dispatches through guest IDT.

Guest ring 0 actually runs on physical CPU in VMX non-root. Privileged instruction causes VM exit trapped by KVM. MOV CR3 in guest: updates VMCS guest CR3 not host CR3. EPT: guest-physical to host-physical HW walk. Speed: 10-30x faster than TCG for compute-bound workloads.
Check /dev/kvm on your machine. QEMU flag -enable-kvm activates hardware virtualization. Without it: falls back to TCG (pure software emulation).
Red border = Ring 0 kernel CPL=00
Blue dashed = Ring 1/2 unused CPL=01/10
Green border = Ring 3 user CPL=11
Yellow = GDT selector encoding
Blue = Ring transition mechanics
Purple dashed = Virtualization QEMU/KVM
Dark green = Hardware security mitigations
GPF = General Protection Fault exception 13
CPL = Current Privilege Level = CS bits 1:0
DPL = Descriptor Privilege Level in GDT/IDT entry
RPL = Requested Privilege Level in segment selector
CR0 Machine Control Register
Setting CR0.PG enables MMU
CR3 Page Directory Base Register

ul.li: Per-process: changed on every context switch

div.p: CR4 Feature Control Register
CR2 Page Fault Linear Address

ul.li: CPU writes faulting vaddr on every page fault (exc 14)
Read immediately in PF handler before any nested fault

p.strong: Hardware steps (~150 cycles + DRAM for TSS):

ol.li: Check IDT gate DPL >= CPL (else GPF immediately)
Read TSS.ESP0 and TSS.SS0 from TSS in physical memory
Switch stack: SS = TSS.SS0 (0x10) ESP = TSS.ESP0
Push onto new kernel stack (top to bottom): SS_user ESP_user EFLAGS CS_user EIP error_code
Load CS from IDT gate descriptor CPL becomes 0
Load EIP from IDT gate offset jump to handler

p.strong: IRET restores (privilege change when CS.RPL > CPL):

ol.li: Pop EIP CS EFLAGS from kernel stack
Detect CS.RPL=3 > current CPL=0 privilege transition
Pop ESP_user and SS_user from kernel stack
Load SS:ESP with user stack values stack switches
Load CS with user code selector CPL becomes 3
Load EFLAGS atomically including IF bit
Jump to EIP in user address space

div.p: CRITICAL: EFLAGS.IF must be 1 in saved frame. IF=0 in saved frame means timer never fires and system freezes.

p.strong: SYSENTER (32-bit) bypasses IDT no TSS stack lookup:

div.p: CS = IA32_SYSENTER_CS MSR (ring 0 code segment) EIP = IA32_SYSENTER_EIP MSR (kernel entry point) ESP = IA32_SYSENTER_ESP MSR (kernel stack pointer) Cost: ~100 cycles (no TSS lookup no IDT walk)
RIP = IA32_LSTAR MSR RFLAGS masked by IA32_FMASK MSR Cost: ~70 cycles
Kernel maps read-only page into every user address space. gettimeofday reads TSC directly in user space. Zero ring transitions no CPL change at all.
CR4 bit 20. Ring-0 CANNOT execute pages with U/S=1.
Prevents ret2usr: attacker jumps kernel EIP to user shellcode. If ring-0 EIP lands on U/S=1 page: page fault exception 14. Set CR4.SMEP=1 during kernel init after page tables configured.
CR4 bit 21. Ring-0 CANNOT read/write U/S=1 pages without STAC.
Prevents kernel dereferencing unvalidated user pointers. copy_from_user() wraps copy with STAC and CLAC instructions. Without SMAP: kernel reads user memory enabling Spectre gadgets.

User mode runs with shadow page dir: almost no kernel mappings. Only syscall entry trampoline mapped in user page directory. Ring-3 to ring-0: swap CR3 to full kernel page directory. Ring-0 to ring-3: swap CR3 back to user shadow page directory. Cost: 2x CR3 reloads per syscall = 5-30% overhead. Meltdown used speculative exec to read kernel mem via cache timing. KPTI removes kernel mappings so nothing to speculate on.

text.tspan: GPF exception 13
CPL=3 > DPL=0 detected
No ring-3 handler causes triple fault
INT 0x80 or hardware exception
CPL=3 gate DPL=3 permitted
TSS.ESP0 read for kernel stack switch
CPU pushes SS ESP EFLAGS CS EIP
loads kernel CS=0x08
CPL becomes 0 jumps to IDT handler
IRET instruction
restores EIP CS EFLAGS ESP SS
CPL becomes 3 when CS.RPL=3
User code resumes at saved EIP
Stack pointer restored from saved ESP
IF bit restored from saved EFLAGS
CR3 loaded on every context switch
Page directory enforces U/S bits
Ring-3 access to U/S=0 page causes PF
GDT entry DPL=0
Only CPL=0 can load
kernel CS=0x08 DS=0x10
GDT entry DPL=3
Any CPL can load
user CS=0x1B DS=0x23
TCG: guest ring-0 runs in host ring-3
Privileged instr intercepted by QEMU helper
Effect emulated then guest resumes
SMEP SMAP set in CR4 by ring-0
KPTI: double CR3 swap per syscall
All enforced at kernel init time
SMEP blocks user-page exec from ring-0
SMAP blocks kernel deref of user ptr
KPTI removes kernel from user page dir
SYSENTER/SYSCALL MSR-configured entry
No IDT walk no TSS lookup
70-100 cycles vs 500 cycles for INT 0x80
